summary: Hemangiosarcoma is a rapidly growing, highly invasive cancer that arises from the lining of blood vessels. It occurs almost exclusively in dogs, and rarely in other animals and humans. A frequent cause of death is tumor rupture leading to rapid bleeding.
risk_factors: Spayed female dogs (higher risk for cardiac hemangiosarcoma)
Neutered dogs (higher risk compared to intact males)
symptoms: Presence of nRBC, schistocytes, and acanthocytes in blood smear
Leukocytosis with neutrophilia, left shift, and monocytosis
treatments: Surgical removal of the tumor with the affected organ (e.g., splenectomy)
Coriolus versicolor (Turkey Tail mushroom) extract (efficacy debated)
